bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 26, 1941

div1.p: Kean makes comments on the contents of the notebook found at the New York Academy of Medicine. He had recommended Carroll for volunteer commission of major, but it didn't happen. He discusses very positively the career of Russell. He thinks Andrus could sell his memoir for a good price. He includes a memorandum listing papers he read about the life and work of Carroll in 1907, shortly after his death.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 26, 1941
div1.opener:
Please give Mrs. Hench our thanks for the pretty
card and good wishes-
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Dec. 26, 1941-
Dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
I have been intending to write
to you ever since your letter came
written on the 30th But I was sick
with influenza at that time, and not
being endowed with the free acting supra
renal glands that the good Lord gave
to you and General Ireland, I did
not seem to be able to do anything but
blow my nose for 10 days and then
cough my head off for 10 more- By
that time the snowstorm of Christmas
Cards struck me and I just had to
send off my copies of the Conquerors
with the Xmas Greetings of No. 7.
done up in mailing tubes- So here
C
K
I am writing
2
with a guilty conscience and a haunt-
ing fear that you will scratch me
off your list of correspondents-
Todays mail brings your interesting
letter to Truby and me jointly, with
the copy of the photostat that Miss Wood
sent you, the air view of the hospital
“Dr. Aristides Agramonte” & the leaflet
about the contract- I did not know that
Lazear assisted Reed in his Electrozone
survey- but it was natural that he
should do so- The names of the Quema-
dos cases appear very familiar- poor
little Jacob Caesar, a little Jew tailor
and his brother Hyman who lived at 89 Rd.
I felt very sorry for them- they seemed
so friendless and so frightened- I think
both of them died-

The urine analyses of Folk Sonntag & West
mentioned about middle of your page 2
I think must have been routine examinations
A. O. would certainly stand for Albumen none
I think- These men were taken ill after Feb 3
I think but their urine was examined to
be sure they did not have some albumen
before the illness- Page 3 M. & P. Rolls
means muster & Pay Rolls, but I didnt
suppose Reed had any concern with them
It may be that he had to carry his laboratory
men on all M & P Roll as a detachment
while they were in Cuba- It must have
been that when Reed left Cuba Feb. 9, 1901
Agramonte was released from the Board
so as to return to his routine duties in
Havana under the Chief Surgeon there-
4-
Carroll stayed on in Cuba until March
1901 I believe but I dont know what he
was doing there- I think that Gen. Stern-
berg was thinking of getting him a
Volunteer Commission of Major and had
suggested that he should be in Cuba
when the matter was brought up-
I had made a recommendation in
the autumn about the Vol. majority
but it never came to pass-

I am inclosing a memo about the me-
morial meeting in Baltimore after Car-
roll's death- I have it bound in with
other reprints and will send you the
volume if you do not find the J. H. H.
Bulletin of Jan 1908 in the library of the
Hospital- Most of the articles refer to
Sanitary matters in Cuba in 1907-8
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
The Nationalization of the municipal San-
itary services in Cuba and other matters
which were very important but of lit-
tle interest to you I imagine- One of them
is a long address by Dr. López del Valle
Jéfé local de Sanidad of Havana at
the “solemn session” of the Junta Nacional
de Sanidad when the portraits of Gov.
Magoon, Dr. Carlos Finlay and myself
were unveiled in the Sala of the office
He traced the record of sanitary accom
plishments from 1899 to 1909 and shower
ed us with flattering phrases, as only
a latin can do- I am going to send
this volume ultimately to the Alderman
Library at the Univ. of Va. where they have
6
a corner for these Cuban matters
including the Yellow Fever Episode-
I am sorry that I did not realize that
you would be interested in Col. Havards
fall report and so I took out the
pictures and threw away the statistical
tables and reports from other stations
in Cuba just because the latter were
bulky. With reference to your letter of
Nov. 30 Gen. Ireland and I had a
little laugh at your inquiry “who is
Dr. F. F. Russell of whom you speak-”
Russell succeeded Reed as the Army top
man in preventive medecine. He made
typhoid immunization practical by devel-
oping a culture which largely did away
with the very severe reactions of the wright
7
serum- So our army was the first to
make immunization compulsory like
vaccination against small pox and in
two years typhoid disappeared from our
list of serious causes of death or disability
After the World War I the Rockefeller Founda-
tion came after Russell and by giving
him 4 times his Army pay & allowances
got him & put him in charge of their
preventive disease work all over the
world- He held this job until his
retirement for age where Harvard grab-
bed him to deliver lectures at their
medical school until he reached their
age limit- I said to Ireland that I was going to write
to you to look in Whos Who, but after
we read that we agreed that it was
a very inadequate presentation of the
wonderful work that Russell has done-
He guided the preventative medical work
of our army 1917-1920 so smoothly and
8
efficiently that it did not make news
for the press- I was amused when I read
the very clever and amusing work of fiction
of Dr. Victor George Heiser “A Doctors Odessey”,
to see that he only mentioned Russell's
name once- You would never have guessed
that Russell was his chief and had
to fire him for not making good on his job-
He also ignored Walter Reed's work in
the same way, and where a friend of
Reed's wrote to ask him why, he
wrote the cleverest letter saying that
he had a whole chapter on Reed &
the Publisher cut it out because his
book was too long! I think Andrus ought
to be able to sell his “Tale of a Guinea Pig”
at a good price- It is so simply and
modestly told- I was delighted with it.
He had a few errors & slips in it which
9
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
I corrected, such as the statement that
there had been no yellow fever in Cuba
since 1902- I heard my friend Dr. Franklin
Martin make that statement in a lecture here
in Wash. once & after the lecture I went up
to him & said “Apropos of yellow fever in
Havana what do you think I was doing
in Cuba between 1906 and 1908”? He said
“What were you doing”? “Fighting Yellow
fever” was my answer-

Well I am running on as old men will
and have got quite far away from
your investigation- I will send you
some old papers before the end of the
year to glance over & threw away-
any that you think of some historical
AC
K
10
interest thought not in connection with
your work please put aside and
pass on to Mr. Harry Clemons, librarian
of the Alderman Library at the Univ. of Va.
He seems to like as you do to look through
old papers. I am happy to know
that you will be coming this way
next month- The hotels here are full
to the doors so you had better let me
secure you a room at the Army
& Navy Club which I can do if you
give me a few days notice of the date
I am sorry I have no spare room here
at home- Every room in Washington is
full they say- I think the photographic
section of the Signal Corps might find
you a lot of good pictures- The Archives
Bldg ought to have Gen. Woods Reports-
With cordial regards and wishing you a happy
New Year

2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Dec 26, 1941
